verse: Abijam [“My father is the Sea” (symbol of chaos); compare Abijah (“My father is the Lord”) in 2 Chr. 13:1] became king of Judah during the eighteenth year Jeroboam son of Nebat was king of Israel.
Abijam ruled in Jerusalem for three years. His mother was Maacah daughter of Abishalom [David’s son Absalom].

He ·did [committed; walked in] all the same sins his father before him had ·done [committed]. ·Abijam was not faithful [His heart was not fully/wholly devoted] to the Lord his God as David, his ·great-grandfather [father; in the sense of ancestor], had been.

·Because the Lord loved David [For David’s sake], the Lord gave him a ·kingdom [lamp; possibly a metaphor for the reign of a king] in Jerusalem and allowed him to have a son to be king after him. The Lord also ·kept Jerusalem safe [strengthened/established Jerusalem].

David did what ·the Lord said was right [was right in the eyes/sight of the Lord] and ·obeyed [had not turned aside from] his commands all his ·life [days], except ·the one time when David sinned ·against [in the case/matter of] Uriah the Hittite [2 Sam. 11–12].
There was war between ·Abijam and Jeroboam during Abijam’s lifetime.
Everything else Abijam did is written in the book of the ·history [chronicles; annals; 14:19] of the kings of Judah. There was war between Abijam and Jeroboam.
Abijam ·died [lay down/slept with his fathers/ancestors] and was buried in the City of David [Jerusalem], and his son Asa became king in his place.
During the twentieth year Jeroboam was king of Israel, Asa became king of Judah.
His ·grandmother’s [mother’s; in the sense of ancestor] name was Maacah, the daughter of Abishalom [15:2]. Asa ruled in Jerusalem for forty-one years.
Asa did what ·the Lord said was right [was right in the eyes/sight of the Lord], as his ·ancestor [father] David had done.

He ·forced the male prostitutes at the worship places to leave the country [expelled/banished the male cult prostitutes from the land; 14:24]. He also took away the idols that his ·ancestors [fathers] had made.

His ·grandmother [mother; ancestor] Maacah had made a ·terrible [obscene; repulsive; abominable] Asherah ·idol [pole; 14:15], so Asa removed her from being queen mother. He cut down ·that idol [her obscene/repulsive/abominable image/pole] and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
The ·places of worship to gods [high places; 3:2] were not removed. Even so, Asa was ·faithful [devoted; true] to the Lord all his life.
Asa brought into the ·Temple [house] of the Lord the gifts he and his father had ·given [dedicated]: gold, silver, and utensils.
There was war between Asa and Baasha king of Israel all ·the time they were kings [their days].
Baasha ·attacked [invaded; went up against] Judah, and he ·made the town of Ramah strong [fortified Ramah] so he could keep people from leaving or entering ·Judah, Asa’s country [Asa, king of Judah].

Asa took the rest of the silver and gold from the treasuries of the ·Temple [house] of the Lord and ·his own palace [the treasuries of the king’s house] and gave it to his ·officers [officials; servants]. Then he sent them to Ben-Hadad son of Tabrimmon, who was the son of Hezion. Ben-Hadad was the king of Aram and ·ruled [lived] in the city of Damascus. Asa said,

“Let there be a treaty between you and me as there was between my father and your father. I am sending you a gift of silver and gold. Break your treaty with Baasha king of Israel so he will ·leave my land [withdraw from me].”

Ben-Hadad ·agreed with [listened to] King Asa, so he sent the commanders of his armies ·to attack [against] the towns of Israel. They defeated the towns of Ijon, Dan, and Abel Beth Maacah, as well as all ·Galilee [Kinnereth] and the area of Naphtali.
When Baasha heard about these attacks, he stopped ·building up [fortifying] Ramah and ·returned [withdrew] to Tirzah.

Then King Asa gave an ·order [proclamation] to all the people of Judah; everyone had to help carry away all the stones and ·wood [timber] Baasha had used in building Ramah, and they used them to build up Geba and Mizpah in the land of Benjamin.

Everything else Asa did—his ·victories [power] and the cities he built—·is [are they not…?] written in the book of the ·history [chronicles; annals; 14:19] of the kings of Judah. When he became old, he got a disease in his feet.

After Asa ·died [lay down/slept with his fathers/ancestors], he was buried with his ·ancestors [fathers] in the City of David [Jerusalem], his ·ancestor [father]. Then Jehoshaphat, Asa’s son, ·became king [reigned] in his place.
Nadab son of Jeroboam became king of Israel during the second year Asa was king of Judah. Nadab ·was king of [reigned over] Israel for two years,

and he did ·what the Lord said was wrong [evil in the eyes/sight of the Lord]. Jeroboam had led the people of Israel to sin, and Nadab ·sinned in the same way as his father Jeroboam [walked in the way/path of his father and in his sin].

Baasha son of Ahijah, from the ·tribe [house] of Issachar, ·made plans to kill Nadab [plotted/conspired against him]. Nadab and all Israel were ·attacking [laying siege to] the Philistine town of Gibbethon, so Baasha killed Nadab there.
·This happened [Baasha killed him] during Asa’s third year as king of Judah, and ·Baasha became the next king of Israel [reigned in his place].

As soon as Baasha became king, he killed all of Jeroboam’s ·family [house], leaving no one in Jeroboam’s ·family [house] alive. He destroyed them all ·as the Lord had said would happen [according to the word which the Lord spoke] ·through [by the hand of] his servant Ahijah from Shiloh.
All this was because King Jeroboam had sinned very much and had led the people of Israel to sin, ·provoking [arousing] the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger.
Everything else Nadab did ·is [is it not…?]written in the book of the ·history [chronicles; annals; 14:19] of the kings of Israel.
There was war between Asa [king of Judah] and Baasha king of Israel all ·the time they ruled [their days].
Baasha son of Ahijah became king of Israel during Asa’s third year as king of Judah. Baasha ruled in Tirzah for twenty-four years,
and he did ·what the Lord said was wrong [evil in the eyes/sight of the Lord]. Jeroboam had led the people of Israel to sin, and Baasha ·sinned in the same way as [walked in the way of] Jeroboam.
